awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Carnegie Supernova Project - Pushing the Precision of Type Ia Supernovae as Cosmological Standard Candles
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds research on an extensive dataset that will provide firm tests of the types of stars that end their life as Type Ia supernovae.  The researchers will recalibrate data to higher precision and gain a better understanding of systematic errors and uncertainties.  Results from this work will help provide tests of general relativity and improve our understanding of dark energy.  Graduate students and postdoctoral researchers will be trained and mentored in research. Public outreach programs incorporating research results will be carried out at the home institutions of the PIs. The final reduced data will be made available to the astronomical community. 

This project will be accomplished by completing data reduction of optical and near-infrared wavelength images to produce final light curves of supernova explosions. They will also complete data reduction of near-infrared spectra of supernova explosions with an emphasis on improved removal of telluric absorption. They will produce new spectral templates for the community, analyze host galaxy properties, and produce Hubble diagrams. Finally, they will compare theory with observation and look for evidence of interaction with non-degenerate companions or circumstellar material. They will also probe the explosion physics as a function of luminosity and light curve decline rate. The dataset will also be used to improve the precision of using supernova Type Ia data as distance indicators for constraining the nature of dark energy.

por.por_cntn:
The Carnegie Supernova Project II (CSP-II) has two main goals: 1) to provide the low-redshift anchor and the spectral templates for future Type Ia supernova (SN Ia) dark energy experiments in the near-infrared (NIR) and 2) to gain insights into the explosion mechanisms of SNe of all types. CSP-II accomplished these goals by obtaining several definitive and unique data sets. The photometric data set is of high-precision and built upon well-understood systems (Phillips et al. 2019). They are also unique in their wide wavelength coverage (uBVgriYJH) and rapid cadence (nightly). The newly commissioned FIRE NIR spectrograph also allowed the assembly of the largest NIR spectroscopic data set for each class of SNe (Hsiao et al. 2019). 


The NIR spectroscopic data set of hydrogen-envelope core-collapse SNe revealed that Type IIP and IIL have distinct properties in the NIR, while they showed a continuous range of properties in the optical wavelengths (Davis et al. 2019). The NIR spectroscopic data set of stripped-envelope core-collapse SNe again showed distinct NIR properties between He-rich and He-poor SNe. Furthermore, half of the He-poor SNe in our sample exhibited trace amounts of He in their spectra (Shahbandeh et al. 2021). These observational dichotomies suggest distinct explosion mechanisms for the observed sub-types.


Using CSP-II data, we have made great strides in providing an explanation for the peculiar sub-group of SNe Ia, known as “super-Chandrasekhar” or 03fg-like. LSQ14fmg is an odd member of this group with the slowest rise time ever recorded for a SN Ia. Using detailed simulations, the observed slow rise was shown to be consistent with an AGB superwind (Hsiao et al. 2020). The observations of the supernova and the superwind are all consistent with the core-degenerate explosion scenario where a white dwarf merges with the degenerate core of an AGB star. The CSP-II observations of another supernova of this family, ASASSN-15hy, established that the core-degenerate scenario is consistent with the wide range of properties unique to this family of objects (Lu et al. 2021). In a third paper, Ashall et al. (2021), we tied everything together with the first homogenous sample of supernovae.


Finally, CSP-II obtained optical and NIR light curves of more than 100 SNe Ia located in the nearby smooth Hubble flow, establishing the low-redshift anchor for future dark energy experiments. Furthermore, both observational and theoretical studies have demonstrated the many benefits of shifting SN Ia cosmology to the rest-frame NIR. Understanding the NIR spectral features is then crucial for these experiments to push for ever higher precision. We have constructed NIR spectral templates based on 331 spectra of 94 SNe Ia obtained using FIRE by CSP-II (Lu et al. in prep). The large and homogeneous data set allows for the understanding of the NIR spectral properties at each phase and for each light-curve shape. We adopted a novel method to produce the templates. First, Principal Component Analysis (PCA) was used to reduce the dimensionality of the observed spectra. Then, Gaussian Process Regression was adopted to model the spectral properties as a surface in the phase and light-curve shape parameter space. The templates are then reconstructed with PCA for each wavelength, phase, and light-curve shape. The resulting templates from these advanced techniques have been shown to largely eliminate the systematic errors that would have been caused by adopting previous templates such as ones from Hsiao et al. (2007) and Nugent et al. (2002). The results from this project will play a crucial role in future dark energy experiments such as that onboard the Roman Space Telescope.
